--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:

> 
> >>=
 This then raises the question of how much HybrID's performance is down
> >=
> to this effect.
> >
> > I do not understand what you mean by this comment=
. Can you expand it a bit?
> 
> Sure. Assuming you did use a cut-off of +-0=
.2 (or so) then I'm
> suggesting that this may be a disadvantage to HyperNe=
at because it
> cannot express connection weights in the +-0.2 range - beca=
use they
> get zeroed. If it is a significant disadvantage then perhaps som=
e of
> the advantage of HybrID is due to it's adjusting some of the
> conne=
ctions weights (zeroed or otherwise) into the +-0.2 range.
> 
> 
> 

Colin,=
 that's an interesting point.  However, I believe the rule in the HyperNEAT=
 implementation is that if the CPPN outputs a number greater than 0.2, then=
 the connection weight is scaled from the range [0.2..max] to [0..max].  In=
 other words, it can produce weights below 0.2 after all because it is scal=
ed to the full range.  However, I'd need to make sure that is actually what=
 the implementation Jeff is using does, but I think it's correct.

ken
